article.title: Epsilon
article.paragraph: aboutthe Greek letterother usesEpsilon (disambiguation)WiktionaryΕɛGreek AlphabetepsilonEpsilon(uppercaselangelΕ,lowercaselangelεorEpsilon#Glyph variantslunatelangelϵ;lang-elΈψιλον) is the fifth letter of theGreek alphabet, corresponding phonetically to aclose-mid front unrounded vowelIPA/e/. In the system ofGreek numeralsit has the value five. It was derived from thePhoenician alphabetPhoenician letterHe (letter)HeFile:Phoenician he.svg20pxHe. Letters that arose from epsilon include the RomanE,andLatin epsilon, and CyrillicYe (Cyrillic),Ye with grave,Yo (Cyrillic),Ukrainian YeandE (Cyrillic).

The name of the letter was originallylanggrcεἶ(IPA-elêːanc), but the name was changed tolanggrcἒ ψιλόν(e psilon"simple e") in the Middle Ages to distinguish the letter from theDigraph (orthography)digraphlangelαι, a formerdiphthongthat had come to be pronounced the same as epsilon.

In essence, the uppercase form of epsilon looks identical to Latin E. The lowercase version has two typographical variants, both inherited fromHistory of the Greek alphabetmedieval Greek handwriting. One, the most common in modern typography and inherited from medieval minuscule, looks like a reversed "3". The other, also known aslunateor uncial epsilon and inherited from earlier uncial writing,Nick Nicholas:Letters, 20032008. (Greek Unicode Issues)cite bookColwellErnest C.A chronology for the letters Ε, Η, Λ, Π in the Byzantine minuscule book handStudies in methodology in textual criticism of the New Testament1969LeidenBrill127looks like a semicircle crossed by a horizontal bar. While in normal typography these are just alternative font variants, they may have different meanings as mathematical symbols. Computer systems therefore offer distinct encodings for them.InUnicode, the character U+03F5 "Greek lunate epsilon symbol" (unicodeϵ) is provided specifically for the lunate form. InTeX,\epsilon(\epsilon\!) denotes the lunate form, while\varepsilon(\varepsilon\!) denotes the inverted-3 form.

There is also aLatin epsilonor "open e", which looks similar to the Greek lowercase epsilon. It is encoded in Unicode as U+025B ("Latin small-letter open e",unicodeɛ) and U+0190 ("Latin capital-letter open e",unicodeƐ) and is used as anIPAphonetic symbol. The lunate or uncial epsilon has also provided inspiration for theeuro sign().
The lunate epsilon () is not to be confused with theset membershipsymbol (); nor should the Latin uppercase epsilon () be confused with the Greek uppercasesigma().
article.heading: History
Origin
article.paragraph: The letter was taken over from thePhoenician alphabetPhoenicianletterHe (letter)He(File:Phoenician he.svginlinex12px) when Greeks first adopted alphabetic writing. In archaic Greek writing, its shape is often still identical to that of the Phoenician letter. Like other Greek letters, it could face either leftward or rightward (File:Greek Epsilon left.svginlinex14pxFile:Greek Epsilon archaic.svginlinex14px), depending on the current writing direction, but, just like in Phoenician, the horizontal bars always faced in the direction of writing. Archaic writing often preserves the Phoenician form with a vertical stem extending slightly below the lowest horizontal bar. In the classical era, through the influence of more cursive writing styles, the shape was simplified to the current E glyph.cite bookJefferyLilian H.The local scripts of archaic GreeceOxfordClarendon196163–64
article.heading: Sound value
article.paragraph: While the original pronunciation of the Phoenician letterHewasIPA[h], the earliest Greek sound value of was determined by the vowel occurring in the Phoenician letter name, which made it a natural choice for being reinterpreted from a consonant symbol to a vowel symbol denoting anIPA[e]sound.Jeffery,Local scripts, p.24.Besides its classical Greek sound value, the shortIPA/e/phoneme, it could initially also be used for otherIPA[e]-like sounds. For instance, in earlyAttic GreekAtticbefore c.500 B.C., it was used also both for the long,open-mid vowelopenIPA/ɛː/, and for the longclose-mid vowelcloseIPA/eː/. In the former role, it was later replaced in the classic Greek alphabet byEta(), which was taken over from easternIonic GreekIonicalphabets, while in the latter role it was replaced by thedigraph (orthography)digraphspelling .
article.heading: Epichoric alphabets
article.paragraph: Some dialects used yet other ways of distinguishing between various e-like sounds.

InAncient CorinthCorinth, the normal function of to denoteIPA/e/andIPA/ɛː/was taken by a glyph resembling a pointed B (File:Greek Beta archaic.svginlinex14px), while was used only for long closeIPA/eː/.Jeffery,Local scripts, p.114.The letterBeta, in turn, took the deviant shapeFile:Greek Beta Corinth 1.svginlinex14px.
InSicyon, a variant glyph resembling an X (File:Greek Epsilon X-shaped.svginlinex14px) was used in the same function as CorinthianFile:Greek Beta archaic.svginlinex14px.Jeffery,Local scripts, p.138.

InThespiai(Boeotia), a special letter form consisting of a vertical stem with a single rightward-pointing horizontal bar (File:Greek Eta tack.svginlinex12px) was used for what was probably aclose vowelraisedvariant ofIPA/e/in pre-vocalic environments.cite webNicholasNickProposal to add Greek epigraphical letters to the UCShttp://www.tlg.uci.edu/~opoudjis/unicode/epigraphical.pdf2010-08-122005Jeffery,Local scripts, p.89.This tack glyph was used elsewhere also as a form of "Heta", i.e. for the soundIPA/h/.
article.heading: Glyph variants
article.paragraph: After the establishment of thecl-spancanonical classic Greek alphabetMarch 2013, new glyph variants for were introduced through handwriting. In theuncial script(used for literarypapyrusmanuscripts in late antiquity and then in early medievalvellumcodices), the "lunate" shape (File:Greek uncial Epsilon.svginlinex12px) became predominant. Incursivehandwriting, a large number of shorthand glyphs came to be used, where the cross-bar and the curved stroke were linked in various ways.cite bookThompsonEdward M.An introduction to Greek and Latin palaeographyOxfordClarendon1911191–194Some of them resembled a modern lowercase Latin "e", some a "6" with a connecting stroke to the next letter starting from the middle, and some a combination of two small "c"-like curves. Several of these shapes were later taken over intominuscule Greekminusculebook hand. Of the various minuscule letter shapes, the inverted-3 form became the basis for lower-case Epsilon in Greek typography during the modern era.
article.heading: Uses
International Phonetic Alphabet
article.paragraph: In theInternational Phonetic Alphabet, the Latin epsilonIPAc-enɛrepresentsopen-mid front unrounded vowel, as in the English word "pet"IPAc-enˈpɛt.
